comment_text.dn14:1.1.1: In the suttas, apadāna means “evidence”, “traces left behind” (DN 27:16.4, DN 24:2.7.3, MN 15:3.32, AN 3.2:1.1). The sense here seems to have been “(story about) the traces that deeds leave behind”. The sense “legend of past lives” probably grew out of this sutta, and later became the title of the collections of legends of past lives of the monks (Thera-apadāna) and nuns (Therī-apadāna).
comment_text.dn14:1.1.2: Kareri is evidently Miliusa tomentosa, known as hoom or kari in Hindi. It is related to the custard apple, not the curry tree (Murraya koenigii).
comment_text.dn14:1.1.4: “Past life” is pubbenivāsa, literally “former abode”.
comment_text.dn14:1.4.1: At MN 71:14.2 and SN 42.9:4.5 the Buddha says he recollects ninety-one eons, which must refer back to the life of Vipassī. We shall see the origin of his name below.
comment_text.dn14:1.4.2: Sikhī means “crested one” and refers to a halo or crown. A story of him and his disciples is told at SN 6.14.
comment_text.dn14:1.4.3: Vessabhū is Sanskrit Viśvabhṛt. It means “all-bearing”, probably originating as a word for the earth. A legendary king of the same name once ruled over the city of Avantī (DN 19:36.14).
comment_text.dn14:1.4.4: Due to the appearance of four Buddhas in this cycle it is known as “fortunate” (bhadda). | Stories from Kakusandha’s day appear at MN 50 and SN 15.20:2.8. There is no obvious etymology for his name, but perhaps it stems from kaku (“peak”) and thus “the union of the peaks”, a valley at the junction of mountains.
comment_text.dn14:1.4.5: The meaning of Koṇāgamana is unclear. In Sanskrit it is often spelled Kanakamuni, “the golden sage”, while in the (dubious) Nigali Sagar Edict of Ashoka it is Konākamana. At Thig 16.1:71.1 we hear the past life of three nuns in the time of Koṇāgamana.
comment_text.dn14:1.4.6: Kassapa (Sanskrit Kaśyapa) means “tortoise”. It is a common Brahmanical clan name, stemming from an ancient figure reckoned as the eldest of the “seven sages”, to whom some Vedic verses are attributed. Details of the Buddha Kassapa’s time are found at MN 81, SN 15.20:4.1, and SN 48.57:3.1.
comment_text.dn14:1.4.7: These numbers make up a quasi-logarithmic scale: the time gaps multiply by three, while the number of Buddhas divides by two. In eon one there are four Buddhas. Thirty eons ago the number is halved, so they had two Buddhas. Twice-thirty eons before that, the number is halved again, to one Buddha, thus ending the scale.
comment_text.dn14:1.5.7: In ancient India, the “aristocrats” (khattiya) and the brahmins vied for the prestige of being the highest class. The traditional business of the aristocrats was land, politics, agriculture, and war, while the brahmins were a hereditary priestly caste who served as advisers and ritualists. It is said that the Buddha-to-be was born in whatever caste was most prestigious at the time so that his word would have the most impact. | In this sutta, the Buddha simply refers to himself as “I” with no personal name. When the seven Buddhas are listed at DN 32:3.14, however, he is called Aṅgīrasa.
comment_text.dn14:1.6.1: The Koṇḍaññas (Sanskrit Kauṇḍinya) originated as the leading clan of the city of Kuṇḍina the capital of Vidarbha, which is probably modern Kaundinyapura on the Wardha River.
comment_text.dn14:1.6.7: Gotama is an ancient Brahmanical clan name, which like Kassapa stems from the Vedas and the seven sages. Why does the Buddha, an aristocrat, have a Brahmanical clan? During initiation by a Brahmanical family priest (purohita), an aristocrat was ritually determined to be a brahmin for a short time, during which he would assume the lineage name of the priest. After being restored as an aristocrat, he and his family would still be referred to by that name. Thus the Sakyans’ purohita must have been of the Gotama lineage. Other examples of this practice include the Mallas who are called Vāseṭṭha (DN 16:5.19.2) and Saccaka who is called Aggivessana (MN 35:4.2). The Jain Ācārāṅgasūtra 2.15.15 records a similar situation, for while Mahāvīra was, like the Buddha, a khattiya, he was of the Kāśyapa gotta, and various relatives were assigned to Vāsiṣṭha, Kauṇḍinya, and Kauśika.
comment_text.dn14:1.8.1: Stereospermum chelonoides. Dictionaries of Pali and Sanskrit call this the “trumpet-flower tree”, but that is more commonly used for Oroxylum indicum.
comment_text.dn14:1.8.2: Puṇḍarīka is the white lotus, but here it is the name of a tree. The commentary says this is setamba (“white-mango”). It is not, however, the mango variety known by that name today (Mangifera caesia), which is not found in India.
comment_text.dn14:1.8.4: Albizia lebbeck, sometimes still known by the old name of sirisa. Older sources sometimes call it an acacia.
comment_text.dn14:1.8.7: Ficus religiosa, sacred to Buddhists, Jains, and Hindus alike. Ancient sources referred to it both as assattha (Sanskrit aśvattha) and pippala. Buddhists today simply call it the Bodhi (or Bo) tree.
comment_text.dn14:1.9.2: Abhibhū means “Victor”, while Sambhava means “son of Śambhu the blessed”. Śambhu is commonly found in the Rig Veda in the sense, “blessing, benefit”, and became a common name or epithet of gods, etc.
comment_text.dn14:1.10.1: The number of disciples diminishes as we approach historical time.
comment_text.dn14:1.10.7: An extensive journey of the Buddha with 1,250 mendicants is documented in Kd 6, at one point of which occurs the events of the Selasutta (Snp 3.7 and MN 91). The Buddha is also accompanied by 1,250 mendicants in the Sāmaññaphalasutta (DN 2) and the Parosahassasutta (SN 8.8).
comment_text.dn14:1.12.1: Bandhumā literally means “one who has kin”. A King Bandhumant is recorded as a descendant of Ikṣvāku, son of Manu, son of the Sun (Viṣṇu Purāṇa 4.1). Gotama, likewise, was a “kinsman of the sun” (ādiccabandhu).
comment_text.dn14:1.12.4: The son of King Dawn and Queen Radiant in the City of the Dawn, Sikhī is the streaming rays of sunrise. These names recall a solar myth.
comment_text.dn14:1.12.5: In Mārkaṇḍeya Purāṇa ch. 131, a Pabhāvatī, daughter of the king of Vidarbha, is said to have married Marutta, king of Vajjī.
comment_text.dn14:1.12.6: There is an Arunawati River in Maharashtra, not far from the ancient homeland of the Koṇḍaññas in Kuṇḍina.
comment_text.dn14:1.12.7: Vessabhū’s parents King Goodfall and Queen Rainy recall a seasonal fertility myth, where they gave life to their son the earth, “the nourisher and bearer of all”. Note, however the variants suppatīta (“well pleased”) and yasavatī (“celebrated”).
comment_text.dn14:1.12.10: The names of the brahmin fathers all refer to ritual offerings. Aggidatta means “offered to the fire”.
comment_text.dn14:1.12.11: The names of the brahmin mothers all recall Indian nakkhatta. These are “constellations” or more properly “lunar mansions”; segments of the sky through which the Moon passes and which are associated with certain stars or clusters. In the Atharvaveda system, Visākhā is the 16th lunar asterism (Libra).
comment_text.dn14:1.12.13: Based on the Ashoka pillar there, this is identified with modern Gotihawa, southeast of Kapilavastu in Nepal.
comment_text.dn14:1.12.15: Several constellations are distinguished as “former” (pubba) and “later” (uttara). Since it lies between Visākhā and Dhanavatī, this may be the 21st constellation, Uttara Āṣāḍhā (Sagittarius/Capricorn).
comment_text.dn14:1.12.17: If the dubious Ashokan edict there is to be believed, this was traditionally identified with the town known today as Nigali Sagar near Kapilavastu in Nepal.
comment_text.dn14:1.12.18: “Offered to Brahmā”. Many of the Jātakas feature a king of this name, usually said to reside in Benares.
comment_text.dn14:1.12.19: Dhanavatī means “wealthy”, but it is also an alternate name for the 23rd constellation, dhaniṣṭhā (or śraviṣṭā, Delphinus).
comment_text.dn14:1.12.20: Kikī (“blue jay”) appears in the story of the past Buddha Kassapa at MN 81.
comment_text.dn14:1.12.22: Suddhodana means “white rice”. He is mentioned by name at Thag 10.1:8.1, Snp 3.11:7.2, and Kd 1:54.1.4.
comment_text.dn14:1.12.23: Māyā means “illusion”. She is mentioned by name at Thag 10.1:8.2 and Thig 6.6:6.2.
comment_text.dn14:1.13.3: This is the only doctrinal context where we find vaṭuma (“course”). The commentary explains it as the “course of craving”. However, in Buddhist Sanskrit we find the phrases chinnaṃ vartmaṃ na vartati (Mahāvastu 2.416) and chinnaṃ vartma na pravartate (Nidāna Saṁyukta 11.6), which recall the Pali phrase vaṭṭaṁ vattati (DN 15:22.6), where vaṭṭa occurs in the next word of the current passage. This suggests that the sense is, rather, the “course of transmigration”, as in the later Sanskrit phrase saṁsāravartmani.
comment_text.dn14:1.13.5: “Principle of the teachings” is dhammadhātu. At SN 12.32:18.1, Sāriputta’s mastery of the dhammadhātu gives him the ability to answer any questions on the Dhamma.
comment_text.dn14:1.17.1: These characteristics of the birth of the Buddha-to-be are also found in MN 123, where Ānanda quotes the Buddha, although the wording is a little different and three extra details are added at the start. In addition, this detail and that about emerging mindfully from the womb are found at AN 4.127. | Normally in early Pali, the word bodhisatta is reserved for the Buddha-to-be once he has left home and is practicing “intent on awakening” (eg. MN 26:13.1). This passage extends the usage back as far as the end of the immediate past life.
comment_text.dn14:1.17.2: “Normal” is dhammatā, a natural principle. This entire passage differs from the earliest concept of the bodhisatta (“one intent on awakening”), which in early texts is typically applied to Siddhattha after he left the home.
comment_text.dn14:1.17.5: The commentary identifies this realm of “utter darkness” (andhakāratimisā) with a cold hell realm. There is a corresponding Purāṇic hell called andhatāmisra. | Asaṁvutā was translated by Ñāṇamoḷī as “abysmal”, but this relies on a commentarial cosmology that is not found in the suttas. The sense, rather, is “boundless”. The root harks back to the Vedic serpent Vṛtra who wraps the world in darkness. | Nānubhonti (“makes no impression”) is glossed in the commentary to AN 4.127 as nappahonti “ineffective”.
comment_text.dn14:1.17.6: The light is a physical one, not just a metaphor. From this, it appears that sentient beings may be spontaneously reborn in interstellar space. Compare the problem of the “Boltzmann brain” in physics.
comment_text.dn14:1.17.9: These are the Four Great Kings, regarded as protector deities. | The term okkanti (“conception”) is a synonym of “rebirth” (DN 15.4.3). It literally means “descent”. Its usage in this context is anticipated by Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.1, which describes how, as a man is dying, his self “descends” into the heart. He loses sense awareness, the tip of his heart lights up and he departs, “rising” (utkrāmanta) with his life-breath, and “descending” with consciousness into a new life, taking his knowledge, deeds, and past experiences.
comment_text.dn14:1.20.1: While sensual pleasures provoke attachment, they are nonetheless a kind of pleasure and therefore a sign of virtue and good past kamma.
comment_text.dn14:1.22.1: This tragic detail is also mentioned in Ud 5.2. The Buddha is raised by a step-mother, which in our Buddha’s case was Māyā’s sister Mahāpajāpatī (AN 8.51:9.8, MN 142:3.3).
comment_text.dn14:1.23.1: Ten signifies fullness and completion, as for example the “ten directions”. | The notion that the term of pregnancy was “nine or ten months” is also found at Chāndogya Upaniṣad 5.9.1. In the Rig Veda it is typically “in the tenth month” (5.78.7, 10.84.3), as also at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.4.22.
comment_text.dn14:1.24.1: In illustrations she is depicted standing while holding a tree in the pose known as sālabhañjikā, a common motif in Indian art representing the abundance of springtime.
comment_text.dn14:1.27.2: Kāsi is the nation of which Varanasi is the capital. Their cloth was of exceptional quality.
comment_text.dn14:1.29.1: This passage implies that Buddhahood was destined from the time of birth, which stands in contrast to the rest of the suttas, where Buddhahood was hard-won by the Bodhisatta’s efforts while striving for awakening. | “Stands firm on his own feet” signifies that he will be awakened by his own efforts. | “North” is uttara, which is also “the beyond”; this predicts his attaining Nibbana. | “Seven strides” signifies crossing over the vast cycles of birth and death, especially by developing the seven awakening factors. | The “white parasol” signifies purity and royalty. | “Surveying all quarters” signifies his universal knowledge. | The “dramatic proclamation” is āsabhiṁ vācaṁ, literally the “voice of a bull”. Other contexts show that this is is an expression emphasizing speech that is dramatic and imposing (SN 52.9:3.2, DN 28:1.5 = SN 47.12:5.2). | At Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.1.1 and Chāndogya Upaniṣad 5.1.1 the “vital breath” (prāṇa) is said to be “eldest and first” (jyeṣṭhaśca śreṣṭhaśca).
comment_text.dn14:1.31.1: Many of the details of the following account were later incorporated into the life of Gotama, under the principle that the major events of the lives of Buddhas follow a natural order. Nonetheless, they are not always consistent with other accounts in early texts. For example, in the Attadaṇḍasutta the Buddha says his going forth was prompted by disillusionment and fear due to chronic conflict and warfare (Snp 4.15).
comment_text.dn14:1.31.3: In Snp 3.11, the newborn Siddhattha is examined by the dark hermit Asita. These two versions are combined in later accounts.
comment_text.dn14:1.31.7: Asita did not look at the 32 marks, and he predicted only one destiny: that he would become a Buddha.
comment_text.dn14:1.31.9: Various “treasures” (ratana) or “gems” of a king are discussed in such texts as Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.3.1.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.1: The marks are elsewhere listed in DN 30:1.2.1 and MN 91:9.1. Here I list the related marks in the Bṛhatsaṁhitā as identified by Nathan McGovern (On the Origins of the 32 Marks of a Great Man, Journal of the International Association of Buddhist Studies, 2016, vol. 39, pp. 207–247).
comment_text.dn14:1.32.7: This echoes the posture of the newborn bodhisatta, and has the same meaning: that he will become awakened by “standing on his own two feet”.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.8: These leave marks that were seen by Doṇa (AN 4.36:1.3). They are often depicted in Buddhist art, signifying the perfection and completeness of the traces that the Buddha leaves behind in his teachings and practice. Bṛhatsaṁhitā 69.17 lists several auspicious marks, including the wheel.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.12: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.2 has śliṣtāṅgulī (“compact or sticky fingers”). The commentary denies that the Pali jāla means a physical web. I think it means that the fingers and toes were usually held together rather than splayed, hence not letting things slip through the fingers.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.13: Ussaṅkha means “(curved) up like a shell”, while Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.2 says “curved up like a tortoise”. The descriptive verse at DN 30:1.21.12 shows that it refers to the tops of the feet.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.14: These are presumably the long, elegant rear calves of the Indian Blackbuck.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.17: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.102 says kings have a shining complexion.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.18: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.102 mentions a “clean complexion” (śuddha).
comment_text.dn14:1.32.20: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.26 says those with hairs turning right become kings.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.21: Here brahm- is an adjective from √brah + ma, equivalent to the Sanskrit bṛṁh, having the sense “grown, extended”. The Sanskrit form here is bṛhadṛjugātra.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.23: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.18 compares not the chest but the hips with a lion.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.24: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.27 says the heart is raised and muscular.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.25: Bṛhatsaṁhitā 69.13 has the same proportions without the simile. These are the normal human proportions, yet we cannot touch our knees without bending. The only way these marks could be reconciled is if the arms were extra long and the length of the legs below the knees was extra long as well. And this is exactly what we are told: the ankles are stretched and long, and the calves are like those of an antelope, whose rear calves are long proportionate to the thigh. Thus in this regard the marks appear to be internally consistent, though not describing normal human anatomy.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.27: “Ridged taste buds” is rasaggasaggī. Rasa can mean either “taste” or “nutrition”, but the use of ojā in DN 30:2.9.8 confirms the latter. Gasa is “swallow” and per DN 30:2.7.4 it is the “conveyance of savor” (rasaharaṇīyo). Agga often means “best”, but this is derived from the primary sense of “peak”. The descriptors uddhagga (“raised”) at DN 30:2.7.4 and susaṇṭhitā (“prominent”) at DN 30:2.9.8 confirm that the latter is meant. The mark refers to taste buds raised in noticeable ridges on the tongue that absorb nutrition and aid digestion. It has often been interpreted as “excellent (aggī) sense (gasa) of taste (rasa)”, but this, being imperceptible to others, is rather a secondary consequence of the mark.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.30: Even, gapless, and white teeth are at Bṛhatsaṁhitā 68.52.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.35: At Thig 13.1:6.2 Ambapālī describes her eyes as abhinīla. While some Indians do indeed have blue eyes, this probably describes a black so deep it appears blue.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.36: Cows have long and elegant eyelashes.
comment_text.dn14:1.32.38: The uṇhīsa is depicted as a bulge on the Buddha’s crown.
comment_text.dn14:1.33.9: This is the dakkhiṇā, the religious offering given in gratitude and respect for the services.
comment_text.dn14:1.34.1: His birth mother has passed away and there is no mention of a step-mother.
comment_text.dn14:1.36.1: Normally clairvoyance and related abilities are said to arise due to the power of the fourth jhāna, whereas here it comes naturally due to past kamma. After jhāna this ability is empowered by the radiant mind clear of hindrances, whereas here it seems to be a more limited ability to see clearly and in the dark.
comment_text.dn14:1.37.2: Vipassī’s name is simply the personal form of the word made famous in Buddhist meditation, vipassanā. This is usually rendered as “insight”, but the sense here is more like “clear seeing”.
comment_text.dn14:1.37.5: Indian epistemology acknowledges two fundamental sources of knowledge: direct perception (paccakkha) and inference (anumāna). This passage shows that vipassanā includes both. I render vipassanā with “discernment” in an attempt to capture both nuances, rather than the standard “insight”.
comment_text.dn14:2.1.1: Here begins the story of the four signs that led to Vipassī’s going forth—an old man, a sick man, a dead man, and a renunciate. Later texts apply the same story to Siddhattha, indeed to all bodhisattvas. | These four “signs” (nimitta) are also called “messengers of the gods”, reckoned as five (MN 130) or three (AN 3.36).
comment_text.dn14:2.2.10: Antepuraṁ (“royal compound”) was the inner sanctum of the royal residence. Maximally it referred to the area enclosed by walls within which the ruling families and staff lived. It later became used in the more restricted sense of “harem”.
comment_text.dn14:2.2.12: “Brood” is pajjhāyati. He is having an existential crisis.
comment_text.dn14:2.4.2: In any story of prophecy, efforts are made to avert it and they invariably fail. This is a recursive property of prophetic myth. If the prophecy were averted, the myth would not exist and we would not know of it; but because the myth does exist, we know how it ends and the prophecy must come true.
comment_text.dn14:2.5.1: An existential crisis takes its own time; it cannot be rushed.
comment_text.dn14:2.10.1: Neither reading vilāta or milāta appears to occur elsewhere in this sense. The commentary says it is a bier (sivika).
comment_text.dn14:2.14.1: “Renunciate” is pabbajita (“one who has gone forth”), one of the many words for religious ascetics. It is a general term and does not specify his affiliation.
comment_text.dn14:2.14.7: “Celebrate” is sādhu, the famous Buddhist words of approval and rejoicing still heard every day in Theravāda Buddhist cultures. It later acquired the meaning “renunciate” but does not have that sense in early Pali. The virtues that he celebrates are common values of Indian religions.
comment_text.dn14:2.15.3: His apparently sudden decision to go forth arises only after an extensive period of crisis and contemplation.
comment_text.dn14:2.16.6: The idea that a whole populace would follow the bodhisatta on his renunciate path occurs several times in the Jātakas.
comment_text.dn14:2.16.7: Following the PTS edition in omitting janapada, which is absent from the commentary and the parallel passage at DN 19:58.3.
comment_text.dn14:2.18.1: This is the only place vāsūpagata (“entered his dwelling”) is added to this stock phrase.
comment_text.dn14:2.18.2: At SN 12.4–10 this same reflection is attributed to each of the seven past Buddhas, kicking off an investigation into dependent origination in reverse order, starting with the outcome: suffering. Here this is treated as a meditative contemplation, whereas the next sutta, DN 15 Mahānidānasutta, delves into the philosophical implications.
comment_text.dn14:2.18.5: The reflection shows how the bodhisatta is still digging into the trauma of discovering the reality of old age and death.
comment_text.dn14:2.18.6: Yoniso maniskāra (“rational application of mind”) is a distinctively Buddhist term that literally means “applying the mind by way of source”. It is mostly used in investigating causality, although over time it came to have a more general sense of “reflection, inquiry, attention”.
comment_text.dn14:2.18.7: Here begins the sequence of dependent origination. I give basic definitions of terms here, and more details in DN 15. See also my notes in the Nidānasaṁyutta, especially SN 12.1 and SN 12.2. | Rebirth is a necessary antecedent condition for old age and death. Note that it is not a sufficient condition for old age, for many die when young.
comment_text.dn14:2.18.9: Since there cannot be an end to the “birth” that starts this life, jāti means “rebirth”, the next stage in the ongoing cycle.
comment_text.dn14:2.18.11: Bhava means “being, existence, life” in the sense of “past and future lives”. It refers to the ongoing process of continued existence, transmigrating through life after life. By itself, bhava has a positive connotation, and represents the longing that many people have to continue to exist after death in a permanent and happy state. The Buddha, however, situates it as just one more dimension of the flow of conditions.
comment_text.dn14:2.18.15: “Grasping” (upādāna) at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self (DN 15:6.3). Grasping has the active sense of “taking up” a new life, not just “clinging” to what one has. It has a dual sense, because it also means the “fuel” that sustains the fire of existence.
comment_text.dn14:2.18.19: Craving (taṇhā, literally “thirst”) and grasping have a similar meaning, but craving is primal desire while grasping is more complex, involving doctrines and behaviors.
comment_text.dn14:2.18.23: “Feeling” (vedanā) is more fundamental than the complex concept of “emotion”. It refers to the hedonic tone of experience as pleasant, painful, or neutral.
comment_text.dn14:2.18.27: “Contact” is literally “touch” (phassa), and refers to the stimulation that occurs when sense object meets sense organ in experience.
comment_text.dn14:2.18.31: The five senses with the mind as sixth. This topic is treated extensively throughout early Buddhism, with a special focus on understanding and restraining the pull of sense stimulation. Āyatana has a root sense “stretch”, from which derived senses include “dimension”, “field”, etc.
comment_text.dn14:2.18.35: “Name and form” (nāmarūpa) is a Vedic concept referring to the multiplicity of material forms (rūpa) and associated names (nāma), especially the individual “sentient organisms” such as gods and humans (Rig Veda 5.43.10, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.6.1, Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.3.2), which are ultimately absorbed into the divine, like rivers in the ocean (Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad 3.2.8, Praśna Upaniṣad 6.5). The Buddha treated “name” analytically as feeling, perception, intention, contact, and application of mind, and “form” as the four elements and derived matter (DN 15:20.8, MN 9:52–54.7, and SN 12.2:11.1).
comment_text.dn14:2.18.39: “Consciousness” (viññāṇa) is simple subjective awareness, the sense of knowing. It arises stimulated by either an external sense impression or a mental phenomena such as thought, memory, etc. It is the subjective awareness that makes the entire multiform world of concepts and appearances possible. Thus far the analysis agrees with Yājñavalkya, who says that the manifold appearances in the world arise from consciousness (etebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12).
comment_text.dn14:2.18.43: Here the Buddha decisively departs from Yājñavalkya’s view that individuated awareness (saññā) returns into “this great reality, infinite, unbounded, a sheer mass of consciousness” (idaṁ mahadbhūtam anantam apāraṁ vijñānaghana eva, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12). Consciousness (viññāṇa) is not a fundamental reality (mahadbhūta) underlying multiplicity, but rather a conditioned process that exists only together with name and form.
comment_text.dn14:2.19.2: Dependent origination normally continues with two further factors: choices and ignorance. The full series does not appear in the Dīghanikāya. This truncated series emphasizes the mutuality of name and form with consciousness, but does not preclude the normal linear series. Each presentation of dependent origination reveals a different aspect of a complex, ramified process.
comment_text.dn14:2.19.4: Note the use of repetition to sum up the main doctrinal teachings. This serves to lock the sequence in memory and ensure no items are missing or displaced, while for one who is reciting the text from memory it provides an opportunity to reflect and apply the meaning in their own experience.
comment_text.dn14:2.19.6: This phrasing recalls the Buddha’s first sermon (SN 56.11:5.1), an insight that is said to be common to all Buddhas (SN 56.12:1.1). Pubbe ananussutesu (“not learned before from another”) means that this is a fresh insight not passed down in an oral tradition.
comment_text.dn14:2.21.2: The PTS edition has vipassanā-maggo here, despite admitting the term is found in no manuscripts and is taken from the commentary, where it is clearly an explanation not a reading (maggoti vipassanāmaggo). This error is followed by Rhys Davids and Walshe in their translations.
comment_text.dn14:2.21.5: Insight into dependent origination here indicates the attaining of stream entry.
comment_text.dn14:2.22.1: The five grasping aggregates (pañcūpādānakkhandhā) are mentioned as a summary of suffering in the Buddha’s first sermon (SN 56.11:4.2). Most of the teachings on this topic are collected in the Khandhasaṁyutta at SN 22, but they are also found in the Dīghanikāya at DN 22:14.1, DN 33:1.11.45, DN 33:2.1.4, and DN 34:1.6.16. The contemplation on the aggregates dispels the mistaken assumption of a self. Many of the theorists in DN 1 identify the self with one or other of the aggregates.
comment_text.dn14:2.22.5: Saṅkhāra in early Buddhism has three main doctrinal senses. (1) The broadest sense is “conditioned phenomena”, which we find in the Dīghanikāya at DN 16:6.10.10, DN 17:2.16.1, and DN 34:1.8.59. This essentially means “everything except Nibbana”. (2) Sometimes it is a physical or mental “process” or “activity” as at DN 18:24.1, where it refers to the gradual stilling of energies in the development of meditation. (3) In the five aggregates and dependent origination it has the sense of “morally potent volitions or choices” and is a synonym for cetanā (“intention”). It is defined as good, bad, and imperturbable choices (DN 33:1.10.77), the latter of which refers to the kamma of the fourth jhāna and above. In this sense it is the moral “choices” for good or ill that propel consciousness into a new rebirth.
comment_text.dn14:2.22.6: The radical thesis of the Buddha’s teaching is the idea that consciousness is merely another empirical phenomena that comes to an end, as is also emphasized in the concluding verses of DN 11.
comment_text.dn14:2.22.7: This indicates the attainment of arahantship, the complete release from all attachments leading to rebirth.
comment_text.dn14:3.1.1: No longer a bodhisatta, he is now called a Buddha for the first time.
comment_text.dn14:3.1.2: In early Buddhism, the idea of teaching the Dhamma only arose after awakening.
comment_text.dn14:3.1.4: A similar account is told of Gotama Buddha at SN 6.1:1.4, MN 26:19.2, MN 85:43.2, and Kd 1:5.2.2.
comment_text.dn14:3.1.5: Here “clinging” is ālaya, from a root meaning “to stick”.
comment_text.dn14:3.1.6: “Specific conditionality” ( idappaccayatā) refers to the fact that dependent origination traces the specific conditions for other specific things: this conditions that. It is not a general principle of universal conditionality (“everything is interconnected”).
comment_text.dn14:3.1.7: “Stilling of all activities” (sabbasaṅkhārasamatho) is the cessation of all conditioned energies or phenomena. | “Attachment” here is upadhi, which is both the things of the world to which we cling, and the inner clinging. The Jains defined upadhi similarly (Tattvārthasūtra 9.26). The dominant meaning in Sanskrit is “fraud”, which perhaps informs the Buddhist sense.
comment_text.dn14:3.1.8: The commentary is careful to specify that the Buddha means physical exhaustion only.
comment_text.dn14:3.2.1: “Not supernaturally inspired” (anacchariyā) rejects the Vedic “channeling” of scripture from the Divinity, while “not learned before in the past” (pubbe assutapubbā), echoing the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta (SN 56.11:5.1), rejects the oral tradition.
comment_text.dn14:3.2.9: “Shrouded” is āvuṭā, which is from the same root as asaṁvutā in DN 14:1.17.5 above, as well as nīvaraṇa (“hindrance”). All these terms ultimately stem from the Vedic serpent Vṛtra (“the constrictor”) who wraps the world in darkness.
comment_text.dn14:3.2.10: Had he followed this inclination he would have been a paccekabuddha, a Buddha “awakened for himself”.
comment_text.dn14:3.2.11: In the accounts of Gotama’s life this is specified as Brahmā Sahampati (see MN 26:20.1 and note). This whole passage is a moment of high cosmic solemnity and drama.
comment_text.dn14:3.3.2: The Buddha teaches on the invitation of the highest divinity. This sets a precedent for Buddhists to refrain from proselytizing, but rather teach by invitation. These passages are still recited in some places to invite a teaching.
comment_text.dn14:3.3.4: Aññātāro is an agent noun in plural, literally “understanders”.
comment_text.dn14:3.6.1: Previously he simply reflected to himself, now he uses his psychic abilities to ascertain people’s spiritual potential.
comment_text.dn14:3.6.2: Indriya (“faculty”) is an abstract noun from indra, the name of the potent Vedic god of war. In the Vedas, Indra manifests his indriya by drinking soma. The drug enables him to release his full potential and power; originally this probably referred to drinking an amphetamine-like substance before battle. Here we see that it means something like “spiritual potential” which is unleashed by the practice of the eightfold path.
comment_text.dn14:3.7.8: Here we see a verbal echo of Sahampati’s martial origins.
comment_text.dn14:3.7.9: A “caravan leader” (satthavāha) guides their flock through treacherous deserts and wastelands, as illustrated at DN 23:23.3. | Anaṇa (“debtless”) is a technical term in the Vedic system. According to Manu 6.35–7, a renunciate must first pay off three debts: study of Vedas, begetting a son, and offering of sacrifices. One who goes forth with these debts unpaid is headed for a downfall. The Buddha has indeed paid off all these debts: he studied the Vedas under his former teachers (MN 26:15.6); he has a son Rāhula; and his path is regarded as the highest form of sacrifice (DN 5:24.1). But in Buddhism the concept is reinterpreted as meaning one has let go of all defilements, becoming a “perfected”, literally “worthy” one, after which one can eat almsfood free of debt (MN 124:38.1, SN 16.11:13.2).
comment_text.dn14:3.7.14: Pamuñcantu saddhaṁ has long troubled translators, as the basic sense of pamuñcantu is “release”. The problem is a long-standing one, for Sanskrit variants include pramodantu (“celebrate”) or praṇudantu kāṅkṣāḥ (“dispel doubts”). I think it is a poetic variant of adhimuñcantu, to “decide” or “commit” to faith. Pali commonly uses a synonymous verb to reinforce the sense of the noun. In Snp 5.19, muttasaddho, pamuñcassu saddhaṁ, and adhimuttacittaṁ are all used in this sense.
comment_text.dn14:3.8.5: In the account of Gotama, he first thinks to teach his former colleagues under whom he practiced the formless attainments. Here we see the start of a tendency in the legends of past Buddhas to erase the education among other spiritual teachers before awakening. Note that these two, who will become Vipassī’s chief disciples, are leading khattiya and brahmin sons of the royal household. Khaṇḍa was Vipassī’s brother, and the priest’s son was virtually family.
comment_text.dn14:3.9.1: Khema (“sanctuary”) originally meant “oasis”. It is common name for lakes and nature parks in the Jātakas.
comment_text.dn14:3.9.2: There is a clear distinction between such managed “parks” and wilderness regions (arañña).
comment_text.dn14:3.13.1: In the early period, there was no distinction between “going forth” (pabbajjā) and “ordination” (upasampadā). They refer to two sides of the same coin: leaving the home life and entering the ascetic life. Ordination was originally granted with the simple call, “Come mendicant!” (ehi bhikkhu).
comment_text.dn14:3.13.4: Thus they became arahants, realizing the same truth that Vipassī had.
comment_text.dn14:3.22.4: As at Kd 1:11.1.4 and SN 4.5:2.3. One of the Buddha’s first acts is to empower his students.
comment_text.dn14:3.22.9: In the Vinaya of the current Buddha, the recitation occurs every fortnight on the uposatha (“sabbath”), and it includes only the mendicants resident in a specific monastery. Here they gathered from all over India.
comment_text.dn14:3.27.1: “Black Plum Tree Land” is jambudīpa, the South Asian subcontinent, including India, Pakistan, Nepal, Bangladesh, and Afghanistan. The number 84,000 does not seem excessive, as the Chinese pilgrims recorded many thousands of monasteries throughout India. In modern Thailand there are around 40,000 monasteries.
comment_text.dn14:3.28.1: The verses that follow form the climax of the whole discourse. They are known as the Ovāda Pātimokkha, the “monastic code for exhortation”. It seems that they were recited on the uposatha in the days before the establishment of the list of rules that is also called pātimokkha. Most of the extant Vinayas still include these verses in the pātimokkha texts, the Pali being a notable exception.
comment_text.dn14:3.28.2: The Buddha redefines tapas from painful mortification to gentle acceptance.
comment_text.dn14:3.28.3: These verses speak of “Buddhas” in plural.
comment_text.dn14:3.28.6: These famous lines serve as a succinct summary of the entire Buddhist path.
comment_text.dn14:3.28.7: “Embrace” is upasampadā, to “enter into”. It is the same word used for taking ordination as well as entering jhāna.
comment_text.dn14:3.28.9: The buddhasāsana (“instruction of the Buddha” or “dispensation of the Buddha”) is the normal word used by Buddhists to refer to their own religion.
comment_text.dn14:3.28.11: Here “monastic code” means the principles outlined in these verses. They are spelled out in more detail in the Gradual Training (DN 2, etc.), and ultimately in the detailed legal code of the Vinayapiṭaka.
comment_text.dn14:3.28.14: The “higher mind” is the four jhānas (AN 3.90:3.2).
comment_text.dn14:3.29.1: The Buddha now returns to the present life. Ukkaṭṭhā is the home of Pokkharasāti (DN 3:2.13.1) and the site of the astonishing and cosmically significant discourses MN 1 and MN 49.
comment_text.dn14:3.29.3: Only non-returners are born in the pure abodes (suddhāvāsā), from where they realize full awakening.
comment_text.dn14:3.29.6: “Order of gods” is devanikāya. I use “deity” to distinguish devatā from deva but there is no substantial difference.
comment_text.dn14:3.29.18: This is a list of the major events in any Buddha biography.
comment_text.dn14:3.29.19: The lifespan in such a realm can be many hundreds of eons.
comment_text.dn14:3.29.20: These are absent in the Pali text at this point, but they are mentioned below, and the commentary says they should be included here.
comment_text.dn14:3.33.3: This is the detailed answer to the question asked by the mendicants at DN 14:1.13.6.

root_text.dn14:1.1.3: Atha kho sambahulānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṁ karerimaṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ pubbenivāsapaṭisaṁyuttā dhammī kathā udapādi:
root_text.dn14:1.2.1: Assosi kho bhagavā dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya tesaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ imaṁ kathāsallāpaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.2.2: Atha kho bhagavā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena karerimaṇḍalamāḷo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi, nisajja kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
root_text.dn14:1.2.3: “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā; kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
root_text.dn14:1.2.4: Evaṁ vutte, te bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.dn14:1.2.5: “idha, bhante, amhākaṁ pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṁ karerimaṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ pubbenivāsapaṭisaṁyuttā dhammī kathā udapādi:
root_text.dn14:1.2.7: Ayaṁ kho no, bhante, antarākathā vippakatā. Atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.
root_text.dn14:1.3.1: “Iccheyyātha no tumhe, bhikkhave, pubbenivāsapaṭisaṁyuttaṁ dhammiṁ kathaṁ sotun”ti?
root_text.dn14:1.3.3: yaṁ bhagavā pubbenivāsapaṭisaṁyuttaṁ dhammiṁ kathaṁ kareyya, bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.

root_text.dn14:1.3.5: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.

root_text.dn14:1.10.7: Mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, etarahi eko sāvakānaṁ sannipāto ahosi aḍḍhateḷasāni bhikkhusatāni. Mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, ayaṁ eko sāvakānaṁ sannipāto ahosi sabbesaṁyeva khīṇāsavānaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.11.1: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa asoko nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
root_text.dn14:1.11.2: Sikhissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa khemaṅkaro nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
root_text.dn14:1.11.3: Vessabhussa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa upasanto nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
root_text.dn14:1.11.4: Kakusandhassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa buddhijo nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
root_text.dn14:1.11.5: Koṇāgamanassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa sotthijo nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
root_text.dn14:1.11.6: Kassapassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa sabbamitto nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
root_text.dn14:1.11.7: Mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, etarahi ānando nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
root_text.dn14:1.12.1: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa bandhumā nāma rājā pitā ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.2: Bandhumatī nāma devī mātā ahosi janetti.
root_text.dn14:1.12.3: Bandhumassa rañño bandhumatī nāma nagaraṁ rājadhānī ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.4: Sikhissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa aruṇo nāma rājā pitā ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.5: Pabhāvatī nāma devī mātā ahosi janetti.
root_text.dn14:1.12.6: Aruṇassa rañño aruṇavatī nāma nagaraṁ rājadhānī ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.7: Vessabhussa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa suppatito nāma rājā pitā ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.8: Vassavatī nāma devī mātā ahosi janetti.
root_text.dn14:1.12.9: Suppatitassa rañño anomaṁ nāma nagaraṁ rājadhānī ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.10: Kakusandhassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa aggidatto nāma brāhmaṇo pitā ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.11: Visākhā nāma brāhmaṇī mātā ahosi janetti.
root_text.dn14:1.12.12: Tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena khemo nāma rājā ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.13: Khemassa rañño khemavatī nāma nagaraṁ rājadhānī ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.14: Koṇāgamanassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa yaññadatto nāma brāhmaṇo pitā ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.15: Uttarā nāma brāhmaṇī mātā ahosi janetti.
root_text.dn14:1.12.16: Tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena sobho nāma rājā ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.17: Sobhassa rañño sobhavatī nāma nagaraṁ rājadhānī ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.18: Kassapassa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa brahmadatto nāma brāhmaṇo pitā ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.19: Dhanavatī nāma brāhmaṇī mātā ahosi janetti.
root_text.dn14:1.12.20: Tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena kikī nāma rājā ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.21: Kikissa rañño bārāṇasī nāma nagaraṁ rājadhānī ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.22: Mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, etarahi suddhodano nāma rājā pitā ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.12.23: Māyā nāma devī mātā ahosi janetti.
root_text.dn14:1.12.26: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṁ pāvisi.
root_text.dn14:1.13.1: Atha kho tesaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ acirapakkantassa bhagavato ayamantarākathā udapādi:
root_text.dn14:1.13.2: “acchariyaṁ, āvuso, abbhutaṁ, āvuso, tathāgatassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā.
root_text.dn14:1.13.3: Yatra hi nāma tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarissati, nāmatopi anussarissati, gottatopi anussarissati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarissati, sāvakayugatopi anussarissati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarissati:
root_text.dn14:1.13.4: ‘evaṁjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipi, evaṁnāmā evaṅgottā evaṁsīlā evaṁdhammā evaṁpaññā evaṁvihārī evaṁvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipī’”ti.
root_text.dn14:1.13.5: “Kiṁ nu kho, āvuso, tathāgatasseva nu kho esā dhammadhātu suppaṭividdhā, yassā dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati: ‘evaṁjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipi, evaṁnāmā evaṅgottā evaṁsīlā evaṁdhammā evaṁpaññā evaṁvihārī evaṁvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipī’ti,
root_text.dn14:1.13.6: udāhu devatā tathāgatassa etamatthaṁ ārocesuṁ, yena tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati: ‘evaṁjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipi, evaṁnāmā evaṅgottā evaṁsīlā evaṁdhammā evaṁpaññā evaṁvihārī evaṁvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipī’”ti.
root_text.dn14:1.13.7: Ayañca hidaṁ tesaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ antarākathā vippakatā hoti.
root_text.dn14:1.14.1: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena karerimaṇḍalamāḷo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
root_text.dn14:1.14.3: “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā; kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
root_text.dn14:1.14.4: Evaṁ vutte, te bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.dn14:1.14.5: “idha, bhante, amhākaṁ acirapakkantassa bhagavato ayaṁ antarākathā udapādi:
root_text.dn14:1.14.6: ‘acchariyaṁ, āvuso, abbhutaṁ, āvuso, tathāgatassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā.
root_text.dn14:1.14.7: Yatra hi nāma tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarissati, nāmatopi anussarissati, gottatopi anussarissati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarissati, sāvakayugatopi anussarissati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarissati:
root_text.dn14:1.14.8: “evaṁjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipi, evaṁnāmā evaṅgottā evaṁsīlā evaṁdhammā evaṁpaññā evaṁvihārī evaṁvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipī”ti.
root_text.dn14:1.14.9: Kiṁ nu kho, āvuso, tathāgatasseva nu kho esā dhammadhātu suppaṭividdhā, yassā dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati:
root_text.dn14:1.14.10: “evaṁjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipi, evaṁnāmā evaṅgottā evaṁsīlā evaṁdhammā evaṁpaññā evaṁvihārī evaṁvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipī”ti.
root_text.dn14:1.14.11: Udāhu devatā tathāgatassa etamatthaṁ ārocesuṁ, yena tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati:
root_text.dn14:1.14.12: “evaṁjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipi, evaṁnāmā evaṅgottā evaṁsīlā evaṁdhammā evaṁpaññā evaṁvihārī evaṁvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipī”’ti?
root_text.dn14:1.14.13: Ayaṁ kho no, bhante, antarākathā vippakatā, atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.
root_text.dn14:1.15.1: “Tathāgatassevesā, bhikkhave, dhammadhātu suppaṭividdhā, yassā dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati:
root_text.dn14:1.15.2: ‘evaṁjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipi, evaṁnāmā evaṅgottā evaṁsīlā evaṁdhammā evaṁpaññā evaṁvihārī evaṁvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipī’ti.
root_text.dn14:1.15.3: Devatāpi tathāgatassa etamatthaṁ ārocesuṁ, yena tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati:
root_text.dn14:1.15.4: ‘evaṁjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipi, evaṁnāmā evaṅgottā evaṁsīlā evaṁdhammā evaṁpaññā evaṁvihārī evaṁvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipī’ti.
root_text.dn14:1.15.5: Iccheyyātha no tumhe, bhikkhave, bhiyyoso mattāya pubbenivāsapaṭisaṁyuttaṁ dhammiṁ kathaṁ sotun”ti?
root_text.dn14:1.15.7: yaṁ bhagavā bhiyyoso mattāya pubbenivāsapaṭisaṁyuttaṁ dhammiṁ kathaṁ kareyya, bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
root_text.dn14:1.15.8: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.dn14:1.15.9: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.16.1: “Ito so, bhikkhave, ekanavutikappe yaṁ vipassī bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho loke udapādi.
root_text.dn14:1.16.2: Vipassī, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho khattiyo jātiyā ahosi, khattiyakule udapādi.
root_text.dn14:1.16.3: Vipassī, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho koṇḍañño gottena ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.16.4: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa asītivassasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṁ ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.16.5: Vipassī, bhikkhave, bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho pāṭaliyā mūle abhisambuddho.
root_text.dn14:1.16.6: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa khaṇḍatissaṁ nāma sāvakayugaṁ ahosi aggaṁ bhaddayugaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.16.7: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa tayo sāvakānaṁ sannipātā ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.16.8: Eko sāvakānaṁ sannipāto ahosi aṭṭhasaṭṭhibhikkhusatasahassaṁ, eko sāvakānaṁ sannipāto ahosi bhikkhusatasahassaṁ, eko sāvakānaṁ sannipāto ahosi asītibhikkhusahassāni.
root_text.dn14:1.16.9: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa ime tayo sāvakānaṁ sannipātā ahesuṁ sabbesaṁyeva khīṇāsavānaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.16.10: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa asoko nāma bhikkhu upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
root_text.dn14:1.16.11: Vipassissa, bhikkhave, bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa bandhumā nāma rājā pitā ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.16.12: Bandhumatī nāma devī mātā ahosi janetti.
root_text.dn14:1.16.13: Bandhumassa rañño bandhumatī nāma nagaraṁ rājadhānī ahosi.
root_text.dn14:1.17.1: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī bodhisatto tusitā kāyā cavitvā sato sampajāno mātukucchiṁ okkami.
root_text.dn14:1.17.3: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto tusitā kāyā cavitvā mātukucchiṁ okkamati.
root_text.dn14:1.17.4: Atha sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya appamāṇo uḷāro obhāso pātubhavati atikkammeva devānaṁ devānubhāvaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.17.5: Yāpi tā lokantarikā aghā asaṁvutā andhakārā andhakāratimisā, yatthapime candimasūriyā evaṁmahiddhikā evaṁmahānubhāvā ābhāya nānubhonti, tatthapi appamāṇo uḷāro obhāso pātubhavati atikkammeva devānaṁ devānubhāvaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.17.6: Yepi tattha sattā upapannā, tepi tenobhāsena aññamaññaṁ sañjānanti: ‘aññepi kira, bho, santi sattā idhūpapannā’ti.
root_text.dn14:1.17.7: Ayañca dasasahassī lokadhātu saṅkampati sampakampati sampavedhati. Appamāṇo ca uḷāro obhāso loke pātubhavati atikkammeva devānaṁ devānubhāvaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.17.9: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchiṁ okkanto hoti, cattāro naṁ devaputtā catuddisaṁ rakkhāya upagacchanti: ‘mā naṁ bodhisattaṁ vā bodhisattamātaraṁ vā manusso vā amanusso vā koci vā viheṭhesī’ti.
root_text.dn14:1.18.1: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchiṁ okkanto hoti, pakatiyā sīlavatī bodhisattamātā hoti, viratā pāṇātipātā, viratā adinnādānā, viratā kāmesumicchācārā, viratā musāvādā, viratā surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānā.
root_text.dn14:1.19.1: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchiṁ okkanto hoti, na bodhisattamātu purisesu mānasaṁ uppajjati kāmaguṇūpasaṁhitaṁ, anatikkamanīyā ca bodhisattamātā hoti kenaci purisena rattacittena.
root_text.dn14:1.20.1: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchiṁ okkanto hoti, lābhinī bodhisattamātā hoti pañcannaṁ kāmaguṇānaṁ. Sā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricāreti.
root_text.dn14:1.21.1: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchiṁ okkanto hoti, na bodhisattamātu kocideva ābādho uppajjati. Sukhinī bodhisattamātā hoti akilantakāyā, bodhisattañca bodhisattamātā tirokucchigataṁ passati sabbaṅgapaccaṅgiṁ ahīnindriyaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.21.2: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṁso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno. Tatrāssa suttaṁ āvutaṁ nīlaṁ vā pītaṁ vā lohitaṁ vā odātaṁ vā paṇḍusuttaṁ vā.
root_text.dn14:1.21.3: Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso hatthe karitvā paccavekkheyya: ‘ayaṁ kho maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṁso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno. Tatridaṁ suttaṁ āvutaṁ nīlaṁ vā pītaṁ vā lohitaṁ vā odātaṁ vā paṇḍusuttaṁ vā’ti.
root_text.dn14:1.21.4: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchiṁ okkanto hoti, na bodhisattamātu kocideva ābādho uppajjati, sukhinī bodhisattamātā hoti akilantakāyā, bodhisattañca bodhisattamātā tirokucchigataṁ passati sabbaṅgapaccaṅgiṁ ahīnindriyaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.22.1: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, sattāhajāte bodhisatte bodhisattamātā kālaṁ karoti tusitaṁ kāyaṁ upapajjati.
root_text.dn14:1.23.1: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yathā aññā itthikā nava vā dasa vā māse gabbhaṁ kucchinā pariharitvā vijāyanti, na hevaṁ bodhisattaṁ bodhisattamātā vijāyati. Daseva māsāni bodhisattaṁ bodhisattamātā kucchinā pariharitvā vijāyati.
root_text.dn14:1.24.1: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yathā aññā itthikā nisinnā vā nipannā vā vijāyanti, na hevaṁ bodhisattaṁ bodhisattamātā vijāyati. Ṭhitāva bodhisattaṁ bodhisattamātā vijāyati.
root_text.dn14:1.25.1: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, devā paṭhamaṁ paṭiggaṇhanti, pacchā manussā.
root_text.dn14:1.26.1: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, appattova bodhisatto pathaviṁ hoti, cattāro naṁ devaputtā paṭiggahetvā mātu purato ṭhapenti: ‘attamanā, devi, hohi; mahesakkho te putto uppanno’ti.
root_text.dn14:1.27.1: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, visadova nikkhamati amakkhito udena amakkhito semhena amakkhito ruhirena amakkhito kenaci asucinā suddho visado.
root_text.dn14:1.27.2: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, maṇiratanaṁ kāsike vatthe nikkhittaṁ neva maṇiratanaṁ kāsikaṁ vatthaṁ makkheti, nāpi kāsikaṁ vatthaṁ maṇiratanaṁ makkheti.
root_text.dn14:1.27.5: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, visadova nikkhamati amakkhito, udena amakkhito semhena amakkhito ruhirena amakkhito kenaci asucinā suddho visado.
root_text.dn14:1.28.1: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, dve udakassa dhārā antalikkhā pātubhavanti—ekā sītassa ekā uṇhassa yena bodhisattassa udakakiccaṁ karonti mātu ca.
root_text.dn14:1.29.1: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, sampatijāto bodhisatto samehi pādehi patiṭṭhahitvā uttarābhimukho sattapadavītihārena gacchati setamhi chatte anudhāriyamāne, sabbā ca disā anuviloketi, āsabhiṁ vācaṁ bhāsati ‘aggohamasmi lokassa, jeṭṭhohamasmi lokassa, seṭṭhohamasmi lokassa, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’ti.
root_text.dn14:1.30.1: Dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, yadā bodhisatto mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, atha sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya appamāṇo uḷāro obhāso pātubhavati, atikkammeva devānaṁ devānubhāvaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.30.2: Yāpi tā lokantarikā aghā asaṁvutā andhakārā andhakāratimisā, yatthapime candimasūriyā evaṁmahiddhikā evaṁmahānubhāvā ābhāya nānubhonti, tatthapi appamāṇo uḷāro obhāso pātubhavati atikkammeva devānaṁ devānubhāvaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.30.3: Yepi tattha sattā upapannā, tepi tenobhāsena aññamaññaṁ sañjānanti: ‘aññepi kira, bho, santi sattā idhūpapannā’ti.
root_text.dn14:1.30.4: Ayañca dasasahassī lokadhātu saṅkampati sampakampati sampavedhati appamāṇo ca uḷāro obhāso loke pātubhavati atikkammeva devānaṁ devānubhāvaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.31.1: Jāte kho pana, bhikkhave, vipassimhi kumāre bandhumato rañño paṭivedesuṁ:
root_text.dn14:1.31.2: ‘putto te, deva, jāto, taṁ devo passatū’ti.
root_text.dn14:1.31.3: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā vipassiṁ kumāraṁ, disvā nemitte brāhmaṇe āmantāpetvā etadavoca:
root_text.dn14:1.31.5: Addasaṁsu kho, bhikkhave, nemittā brāhmaṇā vipassiṁ kumāraṁ, disvā bandhumantaṁ rājānaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.dn14:1.31.6: ‘attamano, deva, hohi, mahesakkho te putto uppanno, lābhā te, mahārāja, suladdhaṁ te, mahārāja, yassa te kule evarūpo putto uppanno.
root_text.dn14:1.31.7: Ayañhi, deva, kumāro dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā.
root_text.dn14:1.31.8: Sace agāraṁ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
root_text.dn14:1.31.10: Seyyathidaṁ—cakkaratanaṁ hatthiratanaṁ assaratanaṁ maṇiratanaṁ itthiratanaṁ gahapatiratanaṁ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.31.11: Parosahassaṁ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
root_text.dn14:1.31.12: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
root_text.dn14:1.31.13: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati, arahaṁ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭacchado.
root_text.dn14:1.32.1: Katamehi cāyaṁ, deva, kumāro dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā.

root_text.dn14:1.32.19: Ayañhi, deva, kumāro ekekalomo; ekekāni lomāni lomakūpesu jātāni …pe…
root_text.dn14:1.32.20: Ayañhi, deva, kumāro uddhaggalomo; uddhaggāni lomāni jātāni nīlāni añjanavaṇṇāni kuṇḍalāvaṭṭāni dakkhiṇāvaṭṭakajātāni …pe…
root_text.dn14:1.32.25: Ayañhi, deva, kumāro nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo yāvatakvassa kāyo tāvatakvassa byāmo, yāvatakvassa byāmo, tāvatakvassa kāyo …pe…
root_text.dn14:1.32.37: Imassa, deva, kumārassa uṇṇā bhamukantare jātā odātā mudutūlasannibhā. Yampi imassa, deva, kumārassa uṇṇā bhamukantare jātā odātā mudutūlasannibhā, idampimassa mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṁ bhavati.
root_text.dn14:1.32.38: Ayañhi, deva, kumāro uṇhīsasīso. Yaṁ pāyaṁ, deva, kumāro uṇhīsasīso, idampissa mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṁ bhavati.
root_text.dn14:1.33.1: Imehi kho ayaṁ, deva, kumāro dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā.
root_text.dn14:1.33.2: Sace agāraṁ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
root_text.dn14:1.33.4: Seyyathidaṁ—cakkaratanaṁ hatthiratanaṁ assaratanaṁ maṇiratanaṁ itthiratanaṁ gahapatiratanaṁ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṁ.
root_text.dn14:1.33.5: Parosahassaṁ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
root_text.dn14:1.33.6: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
root_text.dn14:1.33.7: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati, arahaṁ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭacchado’ti.
root_text.dn14:1.33.9: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā nemitte brāhmaṇe ahatehi vatthehi acchādāpetvā sabbakāmehi santappesi.
root_text.dn14:1.34.1: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā vipassissa kumārassa dhātiyo upaṭṭhāpesi.
root_text.dn14:1.34.2: Aññā khīraṁ pāyenti, aññā nhāpenti, aññā dhārenti, aññā aṅkena pariharanti.
root_text.dn14:1.34.3: Jātassa kho pana, bhikkhave, vipassissa kumārassa setacchattaṁ dhārayittha divā ceva rattiñca:
root_text.dn14:1.34.4: ‘mā naṁ sītaṁ vā uṇhaṁ vā tiṇaṁ vā rajo vā ussāvo vā bādhayitthā’ti.
root_text.dn14:1.34.5: Jāto kho pana, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro bahuno janassa piyo ahosi manāpo.
root_text.dn14:1.34.6: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uppalaṁ vā padumaṁ vā puṇḍarīkaṁ vā bahuno janassa piyaṁ manāpaṁ;
root_text.dn14:1.34.7: evameva kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro bahuno janassa piyo ahosi manāpo.
root_text.dn14:1.35.1: Jāto kho pana, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro mañjussaro ca ahosi vaggussaro ca madhurassaro ca pemaniyassaro ca.
root_text.dn14:1.35.2: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, himavante pabbate karavīkā nāma sakuṇajāti mañjussarā ca vaggussarā ca madhurassarā ca pemaniyassarā ca;
root_text.dn14:1.35.3: evameva kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro mañjussaro ca ahosi vaggussaro ca madhurassaro ca pemaniyassaro ca.
root_text.dn14:1.36.1: Jātassa kho pana, bhikkhave, vipassissa kumārassa kammavipākajaṁ dibbacakkhu pāturahosi yena sudaṁ samantā yojanaṁ passati divā ceva rattiñca.
root_text.dn14:1.37.1: Jāto kho pana, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro animisanto pekkhati seyyathāpi devā tāvatiṁsā.
root_text.dn14:1.37.2: ‘Animisanto kumāro pekkhatī’ti kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa kumārassa ‘vipassī vipassī’ tveva samaññā udapādi.
root_text.dn14:1.37.3: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā atthakaraṇe nisinno vipassiṁ kumāraṁ aṅke nisīdāpetvā atthe anusāsati.
root_text.dn14:1.37.4: Tatra sudaṁ, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro pituaṅke nisinno viceyya viceyya atthe panāyati ñāyena.
root_text.dn14:1.37.5: Viceyya viceyya kumāro atthe panāyati ñāyenāti kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa kumārassa bhiyyoso mattāya ‘vipassī vipassī’ tveva samaññā udapādi.
root_text.dn14:1.38.1: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā vipassissa kumārassa tayo pāsāde kārāpesi, ekaṁ vassikaṁ ekaṁ hemantikaṁ ekaṁ gimhikaṁ;
root_text.dn14:1.38.3: Tatra sudaṁ, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro vassike pāsāde cattāro māse nippurisehi tūriyehi paricārayamāno na heṭṭhāpāsādaṁ orohatīti.
root_text.dn14:2.1.1: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro bahūnaṁ vassānaṁ bahūnaṁ vassasatānaṁ bahūnaṁ vassasahassānaṁ accayena sārathiṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn14:2.1.2: ‘yojehi, samma sārathi, bhaddāni bhaddāni yānāni uyyānabhūmiṁ gacchāma subhūmidassanāyā’ti.
root_text.dn14:2.1.3: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, sārathi vipassissa kumārassa paṭissutvā bhaddāni bhaddāni yānāni yojetvā vipassissa kumārassa paṭivedesi:
root_text.dn14:2.1.4: ‘yuttāni kho te, deva, bhaddāni bhaddāni yānāni,
root_text.dn14:2.1.6: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro bhaddaṁ bhaddaṁ yānaṁ abhiruhitvā bhaddehi bhaddehi yānehi uyyānabhūmiṁ niyyāsi.
root_text.dn14:2.2.1: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro uyyānabhūmiṁ niyyanto purisaṁ jiṇṇaṁ gopānasivaṅkaṁ bhoggaṁ daṇḍaparāyanaṁ pavedhamānaṁ gacchantaṁ āturaṁ gatayobbanaṁ.
root_text.dn14:2.2.4: Kesāpissa na yathā aññesaṁ, kāyopissa na yathā aññesan’ti.
root_text.dn14:2.2.7: ‘Eso kho, deva, jiṇṇo nāma. Na dāni tena ciraṁ jīvitabbaṁ bhavissatī’ti.
root_text.dn14:2.2.8: ‘Kiṁ pana, samma sārathi, ahampi jarādhammo, jaraṁ anatīto’ti?
root_text.dn14:2.2.9: ‘Tvañca, deva, mayañcamha sabbe jarādhammā, jaraṁ anatītā’ti.
root_text.dn14:2.2.10: ‘Tena hi, samma sārathi, alaṁ dānajja uyyānabhūmiyā. Itova antepuraṁ paccaniyyāhī’ti.
root_text.dn14:2.2.11: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, sārathi vipassissa kumārassa paṭissutvā tatova antepuraṁ paccaniyyāsi.
root_text.dn14:2.2.12: Tatra sudaṁ, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro antepuraṁ gato dukkhī dummano pajjhāyati:
root_text.dn14:2.2.13: ‘dhiratthu kira, bho, jāti nāma, yatra hi nāma jātassa jarā paññāyissatī’ti.
root_text.dn14:2.3.1: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā sārathiṁ āmantāpetvā etadavoca:
root_text.dn14:2.3.2: ‘kacci, samma sārathi, kumāro uyyānabhūmiyā abhiramittha? Kacci, samma sārathi, kumāro uyyānabhūmiyā attamano ahosī’ti?
root_text.dn14:2.3.3: ‘Na kho, deva, kumāro uyyānabhūmiyā abhiramittha, na kho, deva, kumāro uyyānabhūmiyā attamano ahosī’ti.
root_text.dn14:2.3.4: ‘Kiṁ pana, samma sārathi, addasa kumāro uyyānabhūmiṁ niyyanto’ti?

root_text.dn14:2.4.1: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumassa rañño etadahosi:
root_text.dn14:2.4.2: ‘Mā heva kho vipassī kumāro na rajjaṁ kāresi, mā heva vipassī kumāro agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbaji, mā heva nemittānaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ saccaṁ assa vacanan’ti.
root_text.dn14:2.4.3: Atha kho, bhikkhave, bandhumā rājā vipassissa kumārassa bhiyyoso mattāya pañca kāmaguṇāni upaṭṭhāpesi:
root_text.dn14:2.4.4: ‘yathā vipassī kumāro rajjaṁ kareyya, yathā vipassī kumāro na agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyya, yathā nemittānaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ micchā assa vacanan’ti.
root_text.dn14:2.4.5: Tatra sudaṁ, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti.
